chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men includes a range of symptoms which can be caused by:
    • Structural or functional abnormalities in one or more parts of the lower urinary tract (the bladder, bladder neck, prostate, urethral sphincter, and urethra).
    • Abnormalities of the peripheral or central nervous system that affect control of the bladder and sphincter.
    • Cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, or endocrine conditions that affect the production of urine.
  • For the causes of specific LUTS in men, see the sections on:
    • Causes of voiding symptoms.
    • Causes of overactive bladder syndrome.
    • Causes of nocturnal polyuria.
    • Causes of stress urinary incontinence.
    • Causes of acute urinary retention.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the causes of voiding lower urinary tract symptoms?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Urinary voiding symptoms include hesitancy, poor urinary stream, intermittency, incomplete emptying, and terminal dribbling.
  • The causes of urinary voiding symptoms include:
    • Benign prostatic hyperplasia or benign prostatic enlargement — the most common cause of voiding symptoms.
    • Drugs with an antimuscarinic action (such as tricyclic antidepressants, sedating antihistamines, antimuscarinic drugs for urinary incontinence, and disopyramide).
    • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy and neurogenic bladder.
    • Urethral stricture and phimosis (constriction of the foreskin).
    • Cancer of the prostate, bladder, or rectum.

[Reynard et al, 2013; National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the causes of an overactive bladder syndrome?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Overactive bladder syndrome is the set of symptoms that include urgency, with or without urgency incontinence, and the sensation of needing to pass urine again just after urinating.
  • Overactive bladder symptoms have underlying sensory or motor causes, but it is not always possible to identify a specific cause. They can be caused by:
    • Benign prostatic hyperplasia and benign prostatic enlargement.
    • Neurological conditions (such as dementia, diabetic neuropathy, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, and stroke).
    • Lower urinary tract infection, sexually transmitted infections, and prostatitis.
    • Bladder stones.
    • Cancer of the bladder and prostate.

[National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the causes of nocturnal polyuria?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Nocturnal polyuria is the excessive production of urine during the night (more than 35% of the 24-hour urine production).
  • Nocturnal polyuria can be caused by:
    • Medical conditions (such as diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, adrenal insufficiency, hypercalcaemia, liver failure, polyuric renal failure, chronic heart failure, pyelonephritis, and chronic venous stasis).
    • Drugs (such as calcium channel blockers, diuretics, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor [SSRI] antidepressants).

[National Clinical Guideline Centre, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the causes of stress urinary incontinence?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Stress urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine caused by exertion (such as sneezing, coughing, laughing, physical exercise, or sexual intercourse).
  • Stress urinary incontinence in men is the result of malfunction of the urethral sphincter. It can be caused by:
    • Prostatectomy or other surgery in the pelvic area.
    • Injury to the urethral area.
    • Drugs that:
      • Increase urine production (for example alcohol, caffeine, and diuretics).
      • Relax the bladder outlet and urethra (for example alpha-blockers).
      • Can cause urinary retention, which may result in overflow incontinence (for example sympathomimetics [such as pseudoephedrine], drugs with an antimuscarinic action [such as tricyclic antidepressants, sedative antihistamines, and some antipsychotics], and opioid analgesics).
      • Reduce awareness of the need to urinate (for example benzodiazepines and z-drugs [such as zopiclone and zolpidem]).
    • Neurological or muscular conditions (such as multiple sclerosis and spina bifida).

[Tsakiris et al, 2008; Reynard et al, 2013]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the causes of acute urinary retention?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Acute urinary retention is the sudden inability (onset over a period of hours) to pass urine. It can be the first presentation of lower urinary tract symptoms in men, or a complication of benign prostatic enlargement or prostate cancer.
  • Causes of acute urinary retention include:
    • Chronic outflow obstruction (for example due to benign prostatic enlargement [common] or prostate cancer [uncommon]).
    • Stones or blood clots in the urethra.
    • Urethral stricture.
    • Severe constipation.
    • Pelvic tumour.
    • Perineal pain (for example due to genital herpes or postoperative pain).
    • Drugs such as:
      • Antimuscarinics (anticholinergics) used to treat overactive bladder.
      • Other drugs with a significant antimuscarinic action (such as tricyclic antidepressants, sedative antihistamines, some antipsychotic drugs, atropine, disopyramide, and ipratropium bromide}.
      • Sympathomimetics (such as ephedrine and pseudoephedrine).
      • Opioid analgesics.
      • Anaesthetics.

[Aronson, 2006; Reynard et al, 2013]
